name: clinker production | clinker | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2795/documentation

The dataset describes the production of Portland cement clinker; in the production different types of alternative fuels and raw materials are used. As the use of an alternative fuel/material can vary considerably between different years, this dataset covers the period from 2017 to 2021.;The CO2 emissions from the use of alternative fuels as well as CO2 emissions from the calcination of limestone have been included in the environmental flows of fossil/non-fossil CO2 emissions. For calculations for clinker, cement and concrete that do not follow this methodological approach, recalculations have to be made adjusting the respective elementary flows in this dataset.

From the reception of traditional and alternative fuels and raw materials at the factory gate. The dataset includes energy use, input of infrastructure and emissions.

This activity ends with the cooling of the produced clinker. The infrastructure of the cement production facility is inventoried in the cement production dataset; the infrastructure inventoried in this dataset comprises the rotary kiln, refractory clay and some wear and tear parts made from steel.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2394:Manufacture of cement, lime and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period corresponds to data collection (2017-2021).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents production of clinker for Switzerland.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Clinker consists of various calcium silicates including alite and belite. Tricalcium aluminate and calcium aluminoferrite are other common components. These components are often generated in situ by heating various clays and limestone.;;Portland cement clinker is made by heating in a rotary kiln at high temperature a homogeneous mixture of raw materials. The products of the chemical reaction aggregate together at their sintering temperature, about 1,450 Â°C. Aluminium oxide and iron oxide are present only as a flux to reduce the sintering temperature and contribute little to the cement strength. For special cements, such as low heat (LH) and sulfate resistant (SR) types, it is necessary to limit the amount of tricalcium aluminate formed. The major raw material for the clinker-making is usually limestone mixed with a second material containing clay as source of alumino-silicate. Normally, an impure limestone which contains clay or silicon dioxide (SiO2) is used. The calcium carbonate (CaCO3) content of these limestones can be as low as 80%. Second raw materials (materials in the raw mix other than limestone) depend on the purity of the limestone. Some of the second raw materials used are: clay, shale, sand, iron ore, and bauxite.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data from the Association of the Swiss Cement Industry (cemsuisse) representing average production in Switzerland from 2017 to 2021.

exchanges.description: CO2 emissions from the use of primary fossil fuels (0.111kg CO2/kg of clinker), from the use of alternative fuels derived from primary fossil energy (0.105 kg CO2/kg clinker) as well as from the calcination of limestone (0.525 kg CO2/kg clinker) have been included in this environmental flow.  0.028kg of CO2 were added as output to close the mass balance as well as to improve the carbon balance of the activity. For calculations for clinker, cement and concrete that do not follow this methodological approach, recalculations have to be made adjusting this respective elementary flow. cemsuisse, personal communication, 2022.

flow.name: Tin ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Calculated value.

Calculated using following formula;
((water_UNO_input+(tap_water_input/1000))*(1-fraction_PW_to_air))

where the input of water in the process (see the variable names of the exchanges) is emitted to air and to water (as wastewater) during the production process, considering a share between air and water, which is described in the parameters.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value.

Calculated using following formula;
((water_UNO_input+(tap_water_input/1000))* fraction_PW_to_air + water_in_wet_mass__fuels)

where the input of water in the process (see the variable names of the exchanges) is emitted to air and to water (as wastewater) during the production process, considering a share between air and water, which is described in the parameters. Additionally, the water in wet mass of the fuels used in the production process is considered to evaporate during the process, and therefore added as an emission to air.

exchanges.description: It's assumed that the lubricating oil must be disposed of after use (the lubricating oil is used to lube the machinery and does not become part of the product). Therefore, same amount as lubricating oil input is used to model the waste.
